title: King Charlges III Coronation Medal Ceremony
description: Congratulations to Branch President Donna Sampson and Branch First Vice President William Law on being presented with the King Charles III Coronation medal by MP James Maloney before a full house at Branch 643 on March 4th.

title: Remembrance Day 2024
description: Branch 643 welcomed members from the public and local elementary students to our 2024 Remembrance Day service.

title: Veterans Resources
description: The Legion provides assistance, always free of charge, to any person who is serving or who has honourably served in the Canadian Armed Forces, the Commonwealth or its wartime allies, or as a Regular Member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, or as a Peace Officer in a Special Duty Area or on a Special Duty Operation, or who has served in the Merchant Navy or Ferry Command during wartime. The Legion also assists their eligible family members.

title: Royal Canadian Legion #643 Amalgamation
description1: On March 11, members of the Royal Canadian Legion Branch #3 and Branch #210 invited friends and family to celebrate the amalgamation of both branches to create the new Branch #643, named after Flt. Lt. David Hornell, VC.
description2: This was a special celebration where both branches united their strengths and ideas in order to make service to their members even better.
description3: Dignitaries of the Ontario Command were present at the event. Brian Weaver, President of the Ontario Command, and Donna Sampson, Chairman of the Amalgamation Committee, introduced the official documents from Ottawa that decreed the new RCL Branch #643. Debbie Olmstead, 1st Vice Ontario Commander for the Ladies Auxiliary; Doreene Corstorphine, Ladies Auxiliary Zone Commander D-1; and Helene Simpson, Ladies Auxiliary Past President of Branch #3, also displayed the document on behalf of the Ladies Auxiliary. After the presentation, everyone was invited to the dance floor to enjoy the party!

title: HISTORY OF THE NEW TORONTO CENOTAPHS & Cenotaph Relocation
description1: In 1919 a group of interested citizens of New Toronto comprising mainly veterans and wives, widows and mothers of veterans formed an association known as â€œThe New Toronto Comfort Association. Their main objective was to assist First World War veterans and their families and to raise funds for a cenotaph that would be a fitting memorial to the men and women of New Toronto who had paid the supreme sacrifice in the war. This was successfully accomplished the same year and on November 11, 1919, the cenotaph was dedicated during the Rememberance Day Service. It was situation on the southwest corner of Lakeshore Road and Eight Street.
description2: After the Second World War, the Goodyear Overseas Veterans Association and the Anaconda Veterans Association met the members of Branch 3 each year, without fail at the old cenotaph on the corner of Lakeshore Road and Eighth Street on November 11th for memorial services.
description3: The Goodyear Vets paraded from the Goodyear, the Anaconda Vets paraded from the Anaconda and Branch 3 paraded from the old Legion Hall on Seventh Street__each arriving about five minutes to the hour for the service. After the service the respective groups paraded back to their starting points.
description4: In 1953 a delegation from Branch 3 met with the mayor and council at the Twon of New Toronto with the intent on having a new cenotaph constructed in a more convenient and prominent location which would commemorate not only the First World War dead of 1914-1918 but also those who gave their lives for their country in the Second World War of 1939 - 45 and the Korean war of 1950-53.
description5: After many meetings the town father passed a resolution that a new cenotaph would be erected on property adjacent to the Town Hall on the southeast corner of Birmingham and Fifth Streets. It was duly erected and was dedication on the Remembrance Day Service on November 1954. The last service at this location was November 1982 as after further negotiations with the New City of Etobicoke this Cenotaph and the older one were both relocated to where you see them today in from of our present building - just in ime for our Remembrance Day Service in November 1983.
description6: At the VE Day Service on May 6, 1984 the members of Branch 3 gathered together to witness the re-dedication of these two cenotaphs and consecration of the ground they stand on as a constant reminder of those men and women who made the supreme sacrifice on behalf of their country and fellow men during both World Wars and the Korean War.
description7: Each year services at the cenotaph are held on the Sunday before November I 1th this being the beginning of Poppy Week on November 11th at 11:00 a.m. a small group of veterans gather at the cenotaph for a short wreath laying service in memory of those who paid the supreme sacrifice.
